utterances: As a member of Anonymous, you're absolutely right.
Rob, thanks very much for the call.
Let's see if we can go to Steve, if I can push the button.
I thought I was pushing the button.
Steve is with us from Cleveland.
I just wanted to comment that I think I can - I've got a good sense of humor, I think, or I could be a killjoy, I don't know.
But I think your work is, you know, iconoclastic.
I think it's, you know, kind of militant iconoclastic.
I think it has a degrading effect, yes.
Yes, I think it has a degrading effect on our culture, like ""The Simpsons,"" like the ""Family Guy,"" like ""South Park.
Oh, don't compare me to the ""Family Guy."" Don't compare me to the ""Family Guy."" You can certainly compare me to ""South Park."" I understand, but you are a killjoy.
There's a group of comics that you're not going to find funny.
But to say that I'm degrading the culture - in order for me to have the feelings that I have about certain things, I have to have a huge, huge amount of belief that things are going to be right, sir.
And I take - I find it insulting.
Well, I find your work insulting.
In the sense that it degrades people's traditions, things people believe in.
What, did you read the book?
I would never buy your book, and I can't believe people are asking your opinion on things.
Well, and I can't believe that you are making a comment when you don't know what it is that I do.
I've seen your work, your life's work.
I don't have to name something.
You can't call someone up, criticize them about their work and not really show any example of what you find...
Your work on - how about your work mocking Judaism?
I've not mocked - I don't mock Judaism.
No, there's people that make fun of Judaism.
That's why I said you're militant.
If you wanted to ruin my day, you did a great job.
Steve, thanks very much for the call.
Well, you know, you asked for no praise.
